title: What are the most popular and accurate firearms of the Old West? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Accuracy is a combination of the shooter’s eyesight, health, breath control, experience, stress level at the moment, understanding of the particular gun’s quirks, and intuitive/rational knowledge of how bullets travel over distance and through wind, humidity, etc. PLUS how well the barrel was made and heat treated, the way the rifling lands and grooves were cut into the barrel, how well the chamber contains the pressures of the black powder’s gasses to put the most propelling power behind the bullet, how the bullet enters the rifling grooves at the throat of the barrel and leaves it at the barrel’s end, how vibration’s handled from the gas pressure and shooter’s own hands, and how useful the iron sights are on that particular gun (installation mistakes or later damage were common, telescopic sights were available but delicate, costly, and rare.) So on long guns, and the longer the barrel so 28–34″ long the better as the gas pressure has more space and time to work in propelling the bullet at a higher velocity: British Whitworth 1874 Sharps 1875 Sharps Borchardt Remington-Ryder Rolling Blocks Ballard 1853, 1860, 1872 Sharps Stevens Davenport/Hopkins & Allen falling block Springfield 1866, 1873, 1884 trapdoors and by the 1880’s-1890’s as smokeless powder became available, barrel and action metallurgy greatly improved, precision assembly methods and screws improved, more adjustable sights, better ergonomics in gunstock shapes, etc. 1885 Browning Winchester High Wall & Low Wall German Mauser bolt actions Swiss Vetterelli bolt actions Austrian Mannlicher bolt actions British Lee-Metford/Lee-Enfield bolt actions Danish Krag-Jorgenson bolt actions Savage 1892–9 lever action Winchester 1892, 1894, 1895 lever actions by Browning Handguns Contemporary tests and accounts are all over the place and the best shots/most active users of these were constantly adopting different makes, models, actions, calibers, barrel lengths, etc. so it’s far less clear than an 1873 Colt .45 Single Action Army model with a 4.75″ barrel (movies) or 7.5″ barrel (the more common choice and much easier to shoot, I shoot both.) There are expert fans back then of the Colt 1851 Navy, the Colt 1860 Army, Colt 1866–1872 cartridge conversions of the 1860, Colt 1877 and 1878 Double Actions, and Colt 1889–1892 Navy & Army double action .38’s. But the Smith & Wesson No’s 1, 2, & 3 models, Schofield, American, Russian revolvers outsold the Colts internationally by a wide margin for experienced cavalry troops and officers for the same or higher price than the Colts. Merwin Hulbert & Co./Hopkins & Allen revolvers were the third most popular worldwide and had higher pressures, many advanced features, and the widest range of models with considerable influence on revolver design, I think they point better than the Smith and as well as the Colt. Remington’s 1858 and 1875 Army revolvers had many fans, particularly during the Civil War when they were as common as Colts and often preferred. There are other makes in the Old West who earned fans and had thousands or more revolvers in use such as Starr (3rd most popular Civil War revolver for Union troops, early double action), British Adams and Webley revolvers, the pocket revolvers of most manufacturers, Forehand & Wadsworth revolvers, Allen & Thurber pepperboxes, derringers, 1849 Colt Pocket Pistol which was among the very most popular of the whole century, and others. John Walter’s book, “Guns That Won the West” is by far the most comprehensive. I’ve seen all of them, own some of them, have shot a few rounds to a few hundred rounds through some, and talked with many gunsmiths (always especially informative) about them up through Bob Munden, David Chicoine, etc.) along with thousands of pages read. I’m reading “The Peacemaker” by John Parsons who used mostly original sources like Army Ordnance evaluations and that’s again changing my mind on many topics with better facts. There’s an enormous amount on this topic based on looking at a few museum examples and extrapolating the world from those, missing much of what was out there in constant use by experts who could pick anything.

I know it's Civil War era. But I'm sure there were plenty in the surplus market. The Whitworth rifle fires a hexagonal bullet. So it was one of the most accurate firearms available. Whitworth rifle - Wikipedia
